title: isBuffer does not works in browser even when window.Buffer is defined
body:
_.isBuffer is always mapped to `stubFalse` in browsers even when window.Buffer is defined.

This occurs because `moduleExports` is always false

Initially i think that it would affect only es version as show in https://codepen.io/blikblum/pen/LwVOmx

But even loading lodash as a script, the bug occurs as seen in https://codepen.io/blikblum/pen/RXPjXy

This will, probably, affect also v5 (master) when running with node with native es module support or a with a bundler that does not injects module automatically (webpack v5 or rollup)

I looked to create a PR for v4 but there's no v4 branch anymore

Should i create a PR for master only?

https://lodash.com/docs/4.17.14

When i start entering text in the search field the page chokes and take a very long time to respond.  Each key stroke takes a second or 2 to resolve.

HOWEVER, if I open the dev console (F12) the search is lightning fast and no lag or stutter is observed.
Firefox has no issues.

I've tried it with all extensions disbaled and in incognito mode as well.  Same thing, dev console off, search lags, dev console on, no problems.

title: Jest reports memory leak when using lodash/fp
body:
**Lodash version**: `4.17.14`
**Jest version**: `24.8.0`
**Node version**: `10.16.0`
**Steps to reproduce**: 
- Clone repo: https://github.com/vunguyenhung/jest-profile
- Install deps: `npm i`
- Run the script: `npm run test:lodash-fp-sum`
  This script will run `jest` with `--detectLeaks` flag on `sum` function of `lodash/fp`
- Observe the test result:
```
 FAIL  src/lodash-fp-sum/sum-lodash-fp.test.js
  ● Test suite failed to run

    EXPERIMENTAL FEATURE!
    Your test suite is leaking memory. Please ensure all references are cleaned.

    There is a number of things that can leak memory:
      - Async operations that have not finished (e.g. fs.readFile).
      - Timers not properly mocked (e.g. setInterval, setTimeout).
      - Keeping references to the global scope.

      at node_modules/@jest/core/build/TestScheduler.js:257:24

Test Suites: 1 failed, 1 total
Tests:       0 total
Snapshots:   0 total
Time:        1.195s
Ran all test suites matching /src\/lodash-fp-sum/i.
```
- Run the script: `npm run test:lodash-sum`
   This script will run `jest` with `--detectLeaks` flag on `sum` function of normal `lodash`
- Observe the result: the test pass with no error.

**Additional info:**
- Adding `--logHeapUsage` flag to see the heap usage, the heap usage of `lodash/fp` version is usually higher than the normal version by `2-4 MB`

**Background:**
We're using `lodash/fp` on production for a while now and notice high memory usage when running on large arrays with nested fields, and at the same time, we notice that our tests fail due to memory insufficient. After tracing down the rabbit hole, this is what we suspect this is one source of memory leaks.

title: Fix: clone certain regexps in Microsoft Edge

labels.name: issue bankruptcy
labels.description: Closing the issue/PR to start fresh

body:
Cloning a `RegExp` _without flags_ failed in Microsoft Edge (observed in Edge 42.17134.1.0 / EdgeHTML 17.17134).

The `RegExp` stringifies its flags as "undefined", causing `cloneRegExp` to pass the string `"undefined"` as second argument to the `RegExp` constructor (which blows up with a `SyntaxError`).

title: lodash ES6 and UMD modules should be provided in a single package
body:
Hi, 

We recently started using lodash(-es) in our project and we ran into several issues with the current lodash NPM packages. 

In our project:
* we are running Karma tests in ES5 using the CommonJs module format
* we are using Rollup (which requires ES6 to work) for our bundled file that is used in production

The current bundling of lodash(-es) does not easily support this workflow because:
* the 'lodash' NPM package only provides the UMD module format (and can not be used by Rollup)
* the 'lodash-es' NPM package only provides the ES6 module format (and can not be used in an ES5 setup)

Instead, both these formats can be supported in 1 NPM package by correctly defining 'main', 'module' and 'jsnext:main' in the package.json.

* 'main' should point to a file supporting the UMD module format
* 'jsnext:main' and 'module' should point to a file supporting the ES6 module format

More information: https://github.com/rollup/rollup/wiki/pkg.module

Is there any plan to support this?

Wouter

title: Prevent prototype pollution chaining to code execution via _.template
body:
Prototype pollution is a common problem for Javascript applications.

[This paper (PDF-link)](https://github.com/HoLyVieR/prototype-pollution-nsec18/blob/master/paper/JavaScript_prototype_pollution_attack_in_NodeJS.pdf) is a reasonably comprehensive resource on the subject. It demonstrates that the problem is quite ubiquitous, and how it can turn into an unauthenticated RCE in Ghost, where the attack chain starts with a prototype pollution vulnerability in lodash.merge. Handlebars is used as the code execution gadget, but as Ghost also uses _.template it could have targeted that as well.

Lodash has had multiple prototype pollution vulnerabilities, [including recently](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/commit/1f8ea07746963a535385a5befc19fa687a627d2b).

If `_.template` is ever invoked after the prototype has been polluted, an attacker can execute any Javascript, as `sourceURL` and `variable` are looked up via an `options` object and injected into the Javascript that gets executed. If the caller is not passing those options (which is the most common usage), then the values from the potentially polluted prototype would be used instead. Here's the smallest possible POC:

```
// If the prototype is polluted via some other vulnerability
> ({}).__proto__.sourceURL = '\nconsole.log("injected code here")'
'\nconsole.log("injected code here")'
// ... then arbitrary code can be injected
> _.template('hey')({})
injected code here
'hey'
```

**I initially reached out via npm security**, and got the feedback that this is not considered an issue. (In the thread with NPM security I also provided examples of how to weaponise this against real applications instead of just the repl example. I can provide additional examples privately.)

I think it's worth fixing, as the fix is simple. Applications that are susceptible to prototype pollution will still need fixing, but at least the commonly used `_.template` shouldn't provide easy code execution.

(I've signed the CLA.)

title: Proposal for a new method `lift`
Clear all memoization cache
body:
(I wrote the first 2 params as if it was a story from agile development, I hope it is fine)

As a developer of big applications

I would like to be able to clear all cached functions with a function call (or an assignment) in order to make my application scalable and not having to manually track every memoized function.
An even cooler function would be the possibility to "tag" memoized functions and clear cache by tag.

E.g: Let's suppose I have many setting files and that I update one of them...

Right now I have to manually `export` ALL the memoized functions related to that setting file in a list (array, map, stack, etc...) in order to be able to retrieve it and iterate over it to clear all caches during my boostrap/initialization.

It would be super cool to be able to just do something as:
`_.memoize.clearAllCaches()` 
or
 `_.memoize.caches.foreach((cachedFunction) => cachedFunction.cache = new Map():)`

It would be even more awesome to do something like: `_.memoize.cachedFunctions.get("myTag").foreach((cachedFunction) => cachedFunction.cache = new Map())`

This would also be cool for testing (so that in case your function relies on sub-functions, you can simply clear all the cache, removing complexity from the test function)

title: feature request: premade versions of fp merge, assign, and defaults with args switched
body:
Currently `lodash/fp`'s `merge`, `assign`, and `defaults` use the same argument order as the mutative versions.  However, it would be nice to have reversed arg order versions available without creating them ourselves.  I actually expected the argument order to be reversed already and was unpleasantly surprised to find they were not.

e.g.
```
> require('lodash/fp').merge({a: 1, b:2})({a: 2, c:3})
{ a: 2, b: 2, c: 3 }
> require('lodash/fp').mergeRight({a: 1, b:2})({a: 2, c:3})
{ a: 1, b: 2, c: 3 }
```

My main motivation for making this easy is that it makes these functions more useful in conjunction with `lodash/fp/update` - you can pass in some values to set as a group rather than do separate updates for each property.

The desired effect would be:

```
> require('lodash/fp').update('a', require('lodash/fp').mergeRight({b: 2, d: {e: 5}))({a: { b: 1, c: 3, d: { f: 6}}})
{a: { b: 2, c: 3, d: {e: 5, f: 6}}}
> require('lodash/fp').update('a', require('lodash/fp').assignRight({b: 2, d: 4}))({a: { b: 1, c: 3}})
{a: { b: 2, c: 3, d: 4}}
> require('lodash/fp').update('a', require('lodash/fp').defaultsRight({b: 2, d: 4}))({a: { b: 1, c: 3}})
{a: { b: 1, c: 3, d: 4}}
```

title: Add support for globalThis when detecting global namespace
body:
I'm working with the Realm proposal's polyfill. The polyfill runs all codes in strict mode.
And lodash-es fails to run in this context.

```
TypeError: Cannot read property 'Symbol' of undefined
at lodash-es/_Symbol.js
at lodash-es/_baseGetTag.js
at lodash-es/isFunction.js
```

Because `freeGlobal || freeSelf || Function('return this')()` all evaluates to undefined.

lodash should add support with `globalThis`

title: omit Angular 8 target es2015 TypeError: clone.function is not a function
body:
Hello,

I updated my app to angular 8 where default compilation target have changed from es5 to es2015.

After this change, omit is not cloning objects properly. When functions of the cloned object are called, the following error is thrown: `TypeError: cloned.function is not a function`

example:
```
sheep = new Sheep();
sheep.age(); ==> 2
dolly = omit(sheep, 'whatever');
dolly.age(); ==> TypeError: dolly.age is not a function
```

When switching the compilation target from es5 to es2015, it fails. When switching back it works.

title: Should _.flatten flat anything iterable?
body:
I think it would be useful if _.flatten flats anything that is iterable, which usually means they implement Symbol.iterator.

The thing is I am currently migrating some of the jquery parts of a web to a native js alternative. The problem comes when I want to migrate something like `$elements.find("input")`. I would like to use `_.flatten(elements.map(e => e.querySelectorAll("input")))`, but querySelectorAll returns a `NodeList`, not an array. Other methods, like `element.childrens()` returns an `HTMLCollection` instead of an array too.

I tried to use `_.flatten`, but it does not work with them. I think it makes sense to work with anything iterable, always understanding that the result will always be an array.

Thanks!

title: Feature request: To consider adding immutable update of object
body:
Currently there is a mutable update that mutates the object passed in. This is an idea to have an update that will return a copy of the object passed in. Such that the update does not affect the original object.

There are two ideas here:

1) To return a complete new object like a clonedeep of the object + mutation of the copy

2) Another idea would be to just clone the objects along the update path. And reuse the existing objects which are not along the update path. So that the original object is not affected. This is a less expensive operation if the aim was to just not modify the original object 

A possible usage is to update state in a React component. Like a lite version of the [immutability-helper](https://github.com/kolodny/immutability-helper) or [immer](https://github.com/immerjs/immer) library 

An example of the second idea is here: 
https://gist.github.com/Lnfra/7854629987682fee44532cf2f96c73c8

title: Get to check for more than just undefined
body:
The `get` method only uses the default value if the value it finds is exactly `undefined`. This makes looking for data in an API response more cumbersome if the value is `null` rather than `undefined`.
For example:
```js
const object = { a: null };

get(object, 'a', []); // will return null
get(object, 'a') || []; // will return []
```

I am proposing adding a flag called `checkType` that when set to `true` checks the type of the found value with that of the default value (if one is provided) and returns the default value if the type is wrong.

```js
const object = { a: {} };

get(object, 'a', [], true); // will return []
```

I just believe that the default value should be used in more cases than what it is in.

title: Fix stringToPath bug for consecutive []
body:
This PR fix the bug for cases like `stringToPath('d[0][0]')`,

**Before** the PR the output is:

```js
['d', '0][0']
```

**After** the PR the output is:
```js
['d', '0', '0']
```

I cannot run test on master, applied this PR into `4.17.11` and all the tests have **passed**, see:

https://github.com/futurist/lodash/blob/c4fd1d90dc9020324ec481977289e4d173097e24/lodash.js#L146

Add _.trimArray

labels.name: issue bankruptcy
labels.description: Closing the issue/PR to start fresh

body:
Here's the docstring:

```js
/**
 * Removes falsey values from the left and right of an array.
 *
 * @since 5.0.0
 * @category Array
 * @param {Array} array The array to process.
 * @param {*} value The value (or values as array) to trim.
 * @returns {Array} Returns the trimmed array.
 * @example
 *
 * trimArray(['', '', '', 'a', 'b', '', 'c', 'd', '', ''])
 * // => ['a', 'b', '', 'c', 'd']
 *
 * trimArray([0, 0, 0, 'a', 'b', '', 'c', 'd', 0, 0], 0)
 * // => ['a', 'b', '', 'c', 'd']
 *
 * trimArray([0, 1, 2, 'a', 'b', '', 'c', 'd', 0, 1], [0, 1, 2])
 * // => ['a', 'b', '', 'c', 'd']
 */
```

title: Lodash drastically grew in size from v3 to v4
body:
Hello,
i've just updated lodash from 3.10.1 to 4.17.11 and the size of partially required functions grew from 16.61kb to 30.79kb (minified). This is how i required necessary functions:

```
var merge = require('lodash/object/merge'),
    clone = require('lodash/lang/clone'),
    isObject = require('lodash/lang/isObject'),
    isUndefined = require('lodash/lang/isUndefined'),
    isString = require('lodash/lang/isString'),
    isEmpty = require('lodash/lang/isEmpty'),
    map = require('lodash/collection/map'),
    each = require('lodash/collection/each'),
    includes = require('lodash/collection/includes'),
    debounce = require('lodash/function/debounce'),
    findIndex = require('lodash/array/findIndex');

module.exports = {
    merge,
    clone,
    isObject,
    isUndefined,
    isEmpty,
    isString,
    each,
    map,
    includes,
    debounce,
    findIndex
};
```
The required paths were rewritten after update like `var merge = require('lodash/object/merge'),` to `var merge = require('lodash/merge'),`
Is there something i'm doing wrong? I don't think the doubling of the size is normal.

Best regards,
dr0bz

title: Rename flowRight -> compose
body:
The `flowRight` method is just a confusing name for `compose`, I end up doing this in every project:
```js
import { flowRight as compose } from 'lodash';
```

My proposal is to rename the `flowRight` to simply `compose` or at least aliasing the `flowRight` method for a couple of releases deprecating it asap.

title: Rename lowerCase to something more intuitive like lowerSpaceCase or something
body:
A quick search of issues here on github, and a quick google search, and my angry coworker (lol) tells me a lot of people get bitten by unexpected string modification behavior when they use the lowerCase() method, as they expect it to behave like toLower() does. I see why, and feel like I easily could have made the same mistake.

I understand the name matches your convention of your other *Case methods, but I still think you should change the name to something that is less likely to be misinterpreted so easily.

v8 Allocation - JS heap out of memory
body:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/26691026/57576510-2edc8680-742f-11e9-928c-1b930473cc61.png)

###  Steps to reproduce:
* Start a program that will not exit unless killed manually ~~until CTRL+C is pressed (SIGINT)~~
* ~~Send SIGINT, in my case that's simply CTRL+C~~
* Wait a few seconds
* Error, crash.

### What was I doing to possibly trigger this crash?
I have no idea, other than I have a watchdog file that keeps my databases in order. Specifically, I use sqlite3 and Sequelize (lodash is dependency) to configure them.. not sure if that matters? Figured I'd put it in there in case. I was having an issue with it a few minutes ago where the DBs were locking up due to performing actions too quickly, stupid me for not async'ing it.

I'm posting this issue here because the stack trace included you guys. Sorry if that wasn't quite the right thing to do, but I'm not sure what else to do.

## Edit - The next morning
Doing some developing again and I noticed that I didn't even have to send a kill signal. It just crashed on its own.
Same problem, still you guys, but different error this time:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/26691026/57582519-c07ddf80-7493-11e9-91b8-c6c1610c3f98.png)

Minor edit: Disabled the watchdog and problem no longer occurs.

title: realNames failing to check .hasOwnProperty()
body:
this patch fixes a problem that breaks lodash in the presence of object prototype functions.  the issue arises from lodash's failure to check the .hasOwnProperty() on keys within the realNames object, which pulls up these methods when it shouldn't

WARNING: there may be other places in the code failing this but so far this is the only instance I've discovered

title: In loadash-es, package.json should include "type":"module"
body:
In nodejs 12 with the "--experimental-modules", es (es6/esm) modules can be loaded.

But for that to work, for the file to be considered by nodejs as a esm module, by either end in .mjs or
because its package.json must specify "type: module".

Since lodash-es is specifically an es module, I suggest that its package.json contain "type: module". So that it can be loaded in nodejs also.

That should have no other side effects.

Documentation for nodejs here: https://nodejs.org/dist/latest-v12.x/docs/api/esm.html#esm_code_package_json_code_code_type_code_field

Why do I want that?

Well, I developp some es modules that need to work on both the server and the client, without any "bundling". So my module use lodash-es. Today, it can not be loaded in nodejs because nodejs consider it as a cjs (commonJS) module. This should do the trick.

Community Invitation to the OpenJS Collaborator Summit + Info
body:
*Hi all! In an effort to make sure we're fully getting the word out to OpenJS Foundation project communities about the collaborator summit, I'm posting the following message on main or admin repos:* 

This year, the Node Collaborator summit is opening up to include and welcome all former JS Foundation projects. The Collaborator summit is a space where projects and working groups within projects have the dedicated time and space to get together and get work done. We will have project-specific meetings, cross-project meetings on issues like security and standards, and of course meetings to discuss new programs and patterns for the new CPC. 

The event will be in Berlin on May 30-31st at the Courtyard Marriott City Center. It is free to register with the password 'collabsummit.' We are also inviting all projects/attendees to suggest meetings and sessions via our CFP - these are not conference talks, but rather collaborative conversations or meetings you would like to hold with your peers. We ask that you register in advance so that we can allocate meeting room space and resources, and so that we can publish where conversations are scheduled in the day or two leading up to the event.

Links:
* [Session Proposals](https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLScneYhY4iqm8x2C2AO9EEzJ5smkOKhLqfxEMQcfNvP5rvXfHg/viewform?usp=sf_link)
* [Registration](https://www.eventbrite.com/e/openjs-collaborator-summit-tickets-55985971548) (password is collabsummit)
* Information on how to apply for the [Travel Fund](https://github.com/nodejs/admin/blob/master/MEMBER_TRAVEL_FUND.md)
* [Summit Planning Repo](https://github.com/nodejs/summit/issues)

title: What does "successive invocation" mean in the docs for reduce?
body:
I am implementing a deep version of `reduce` and want it to conform to its flat prototype.
From the docs:

> Reduces collection to a value which is the accumulated result of running each element in collection thru iteratee, where each **successive** invocation is supplied the return value of the previous.

Looks like word "successive" reflects nothing in the behavior of this method. 
`undefined` or `false` value returned from iteratee is accepted as a new accumulator value by the same way as any other value.
I also see no try/catch in the sources, so throwing an error is not an option too.
Native Array `reduce` method also doesn't suppose any difference.
Maybe it's some relict from the older versions?
